ALLEGATION:
Agency workers placed five-year-old Child A into a shelter from 10/22/2021-10/29/
2021 in violation of DHHS policy; and without obtaining approval from the Children
Service Agency Director.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/4/2021 I reviewed the complaint.
On 11/8/2021I spoke with the LGAL (Lawyer Guardian, Ad Litem) by telephone.
The LGAL reported Child A was supposed to be residing with Child A’s
grandmother in New York. On 10/22/2021, Child A was placed in a shelter in the
Bronx of New York. DHHS-Western Wayne (WW)did not notify her of Child A’s
removal from the grandmother’s home or the shelter placement. An attorney in New
York, contacted her about the change on 10/29/2021, a week after Child A’s
removal from the grandmother’s home.
The LGAL expressed concern that Child A’s shelter placement occurred without
adherence to DHHS policy mandates. Further that DHHS-WW allowed five-year-old
Child A to be placed in and remain in a shelter for a week. The LGAL reported that
when the court gave permission for Child A to be placed with the grandmother in
New York, DHHS-WW removed him from the foster home of Foster Parents (FPS)
XX in a day, with police assistance, but they left Child A in a shelter for a week.
On 11/12/2021 I spoke with Administrator 1, Supervisor 2, Program Manager 3, and
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4 via a TEAM video contact. I also received email
information from Administrator 1 on 11/16/2021. These staff affirmed Child A’s
3

placement in a New York Shelter for the time period indicated in the complaint. They
denied authorizing it. They arranged for Child A’s return to Michigan as quickly as
they could and that occurred on 10/29/2021.
Administrator 1 and Supervisor 3 advised that Child A was placed with his maternal
grandmother, Relative O. DHHS-WW did not become aware of Child A’s placement
in a New York shelter until after the fact. New York replaced Child A without notifying
DHHS-WW until 10/25/2021. On 10/25/2021 New York informed them of the
replacement and shared information related to an additional possible abuse/neglect
allegations in Relative O’s home that lead to the placement change.
Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 reported New York reported that on 10/22/2021 Child A
had parenting time with his mother and New York discovered Child A had an
additional bruise. FCW 4 reported that’s when she became aware of Child A having
a black eye.
Administrator 1 reported once DHHS-WW was notified of Child A’s placement in the
shelter on 10/25/2021, DHHS-WW conferenced with New York that same day, as
well as on 10/26/2021 to determine if Child A could remain in New York in a safety
plan. New York was not in agreement with identifying an in-state safety plan.
Therein, DHHS-WW consulted with the Interstate Compact on the Placement of
Children (ICPC). ICPC advised them they needed to pick up Child A within five days
of receiving notice that Child A was replaced from the ICPC approved placement
with Child’s grandmother. They coordinated with ICPC and New York to set up
travel arrangements for Child A. Therein, they began making arrangements for
Child A’s return to Michigan. Child A’s return on 10/29/2021 was the earlier that
could be expedited.
Reviewed:
Child A MISACWIS case record which showed:
 Child A entered care on 11/10/2016; and was placed in the licensed foster
home of FPS XX.
 Child A was placed in an adoptive placement with FPS XX in April 2019
following termination of his birth parent’s rights parental right in June 2018.
The adoptive placement was altered in February 2020 when the court
reinstated the birth mother’s parental rights following an appeal by her of
Child A’s permanent custody.
 Child A was placed with his maternal grandmother, Relative O on 8/14/2021.
He was removed from Relative O’s care on 10/22/2021.
 On 10/29/2021 Child A was returned to Michigan and was placed with Foster
Parents Z.
 Foster Care Placement Decision Notice (DHS-31) showing a replacement for
Child A from Relative O to Foster Parents Z.
 Two Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summaries (DHS-69). One showing
Child A’s replacement from Relative O’s home to a shelter in New York on
4

10/22/2021. Another showing Child A’s replacement from the shelter to the
Foster Parent Z’s foster home on 10/29/2021.
 A 10/28/2021 social work contact entered 11/16/2021 by Supervisor 3 that
indicated New York was emailed travel plans for Child A.
 A 10/29/2021 social work contact entered 11/15/2021, by FCW 4. The contact
indicated FCW 4 completed a flight to New York and transported Child A to
Foster Parents Z’s foster home in Michigan this date.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-03E Placement exception request.
Pre-10 Placement Exception:
The Children's Services Agency (CSA) executive director must
grant final approval for the following residential PER types for a
child under the age of 10:
• Residential Placement - Initial.
The BSC director must grant final approval for all other
residential PERs for children under 10 years of age.
ANALYSIS: The evidence does not show a lack of action or effort to comply
to this standard. DHHS-WW did not place Child A into a shelter.
They did not receive notification of New York’s Children
Services’ action of replacing Child A from Relative O’s home
into a shelter until 10/25/2021. DHHS-WW did not have control
over New York’s actions or New York’s delay in contacting
DHHS-WW.
DHHS-WW asked for a safety plan for Child A. New York
requested Child A’s return to his state of jurisdiction. Therein,
DHHS-WW, focused on getting Child A out of the shelter and
back to Michigan as quickly as they could. They secured Child
A’s replacement to Michigan on 10/29/2021.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
(1) The agency workers failed to notify the court or LGAL of Child A’s change of
placement until after 10/22/2021 and did not disclose the shelter placement at that
time.
(2) The agency misrepresented information in reports in an attempt to hide Child A’s
shelter placement.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/8/2021 I spoke with the LGAL by telephone. The LGAL reported DHHS-WW
did not notify her of Child A’s removal from the grandmother’s home, and Child A’s
shelter placement. An attorney in New York, contacted her about the change on
10/29/2021, a week after Child A’s removal from the grandmother’s home. The LGAL
5

reported DHHS-WW FCW 4 sent the LGAL an email at 12:22pm on 10/26/2021
advising of a Team Decision Meeting (TDM) set for 1:00pm on 10/27/2021. The
email did not address that the purpose of the TDM related to a placement change or
shelter placement for Child A. The LGAL reported she responded to FCW 4’s email
later that day asking for the agenda for the TDM, and whether DHHS-WW was
considering a placement change for Child A, and what is that change. FCW 4 never
responded to her request for information related to the purpose of the TDM or request
for complaint information. On 10/27/2021 FCW 4 sent another email to the LGAL
changing the TDM date and time to 10/28/2021 at 10:30am. FCW 4 never reached
out to the LGAL to check her availability, nor reported in the emails that Child A had
been removed from the grandmother’s home.
The LGAL reported Child A was returned to Michigan on 10/29/2021. DHHS-WW
placed Child A in a foster home in New Hudson but did not timely supply the LGAL
with contact information for Child A’s new foster parents. The LGAL had to reach out
to DHHS-WW for that information. The LGAL reported when DHHS-WW sent her
documentation of Child A’s replacement to Foster Parents Z’s foster home, it gave
the impression he was placed there from Relative’s O home, which was not the case.
They tried to hide the shelter placement. The FCW misrepresented information in
reports related to Child A’s placement change.
I reviewed Information provided to me by the LGAL which showed:
 On 10/29/2021 Supervisor 3 emailed the DHS-31(Foster Care Placement
Decision Notice) showing Child A’s placement with Foster Parents Z and
Parents Z’s address, but not Foster Parents Z’s telephone number.
 On 11/1/2021 Program Manager 2 emailed the LGAL Foster Parents Z’s
telephone number.
 On 11/2/2021 DHHS-WW emailed the LGAL two DHS-69s(Foster
care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary) dated 10/29/2021.
On 11/12/2021 I spoke with Administrator 1, Supervisor 2, Program Manager 3, and
FCW 4 about the allegations via a TEAM’s video contact. Program Manager 2, and
Supervisor 3 reported they apprised DHHS’s attorney, the Assistant Attorney General
(AAG) via email of the situation of Child A’s replacement when they became aware of it
on 10/25/2021. They also conferenced with the AAG about the matter on 10/25/2021.
The AAG reported he would apprise the LGAL of the situation. Administrator 1 reported
that in the past they have had direct contact with an LGAL, but typically they have
contact with the AAG. They reported although they shared the information with the
AAG, FCW 4 was to notify the LGAL, but she “dropped the ball” on that.
FCW 4 reported that with all that was going on, “it passed me by”, and she did not
contact the LGAL on 10/25/2021. She reported sending the LGAL an TDM invite on
10/26/2021 and again on 10/27/2021, when the TDM was changed from 10/27/2021 to
10/28/2021, due to not being able to get into touch with Child A’s mother’s attorney.
FCW 4 acknowledged that the LGAL requested more information about the scheduled
TDM. Whether the TDM was about a placement change. FCW 4 admitted she did not
6

reply to that email. She reported not knowing whether the LGAL knew or did not know if
Child A was placed in a shelter. The LGAL did not attended the TDM. The FCW 4 did
not provide the LGAL with a copy of the outcome of the TDM (FTM-Family team
meeting) DHS-1105, which may have provided the LGAL information about the shelter
placement and how it came to be. Supervisor 3 interjected that, typically they would not
send a copy of the DHS-1105 to the LGAL, because the LGAL was not in attendance
and did not request a copy. Supervisor 3 advised even if they had, given that the TDM
was conducted by a facilitator not FCW 4, by the time the DHS-1105 report would have
been written, Child A was already replaced/retuned to Michigan on 10/29/2021.
Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 both acknowledged the LGAL was provided a DHS-31 via
email related to the Child A replacement/return home to Michigan, on 10/29/2021. FCW
4 admitted the DHS-31 appeared as if Child A went from Relative O’s home to Foster
Parents Z’s home. Supervisor 3 reported the latter was due to FCW 4 not having the
specific information/address for the shelter. FCW 4 admitted it would have been
possible for her to have completed the DHS-31 entering just the New York shelter
without it’s address, but she was busy trying to get other matters completed. She said
she followed up with a DHS-69 action summary that showed Child A’s placement from
the shelter to Foster Parents Z’s home in Michigan.
Reviewed:
Child A MISACWIS case record which showed:
 Child A was replaced from Relative O’s home on 10/22/2021 and placed in a
New York Shelter.
 A 10/28/2021 FTM (Family Team Meeting/ for TDM) for a TEAM’s video TDM
documentation which showed DHHS-WW indicating DHHS- foster care staff
would fly to New York to pick up Child A and return him to Michigan. New
York CPS had received complaints of physical abuse while Child A was in
Relative O’s care. Child A would remain in New York’s Children services’
custody, in the shelter placement until he leaves New York. That, per
Michigan ICPC (Interstate Placement of Children) DHHS-WW has five days to
remove Child A and place his elsewhere.
 A Foster Care Placement Decision Notice (DHS-31) showing Child A
replacement from Relative O to Foster Parents Z’s home on 10/29/2021.
 Two Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summaries (DHS-69). One showing
Child A’s replacement from Relative O’s home to a shelter in New York on
10/22/2021. Another showing Child A’s replacement from the shelter to Foster
Parents Z’s foster home on 10/29/2021.
 A copy of a 10/26/2021 emails from DHHS- WW for a 10/27/2021 TDM for
Child A related to Placement stability. The LGAL was included in the email.
The emails did not list an agenda.
 A copy of an 10/26/2021 email from the LGAL asking for agenda topics for
the TDM and whether DHHS was considering a change of placement, and if
so, the proposed new placement.
 A copy of a 10/8/2021 email between the AAG and FCW 4 where the AAG
advised FCW 4 to keep him up to speed on the abuse/neglect allegations
7

pertaining to Child A’s relatives; and that if there is a change of placement
FCW 4 should immediately notify him and the LGAL.
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child’s record before a change in placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem and courts when applicable of the change
in placement.
ANALYSIS: The agency did not directly or timely contact the LGAL to inform
her of Child A’ placement into a shelter when they became
aware of it on 10/25/2021. They submitted a DHS-69 showing
that placement change to the LGAL on 11/2/2021, which was
also after the required timeframe connected to DHHS policy.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.12206 Staff qualifications.
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the
duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to support that the agency
purposefully misrepresented placement information on the DHS-
31. Nor that the agency tried to conceal Child A’s placement in a
New York shelter.
The worker’s completion of the DHS-31 was very inadequate in
that she did not take the time to ensure its accuracy or correct it.
The follow up documents the agency provided the LGAL via two
Action Summaries (DHS-69) showed the placement scenario
accurately. One DHS-69 showed Child A’s placement from his
grandmother’s home to a New York shelter, the other his
placement from the New York shelter to Foster Parents Z’s
home in Michigan.
The evidence does not show the staff’s inability or lack of
education or experience to perform the duties assigned.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
8

ALLEGATION:
The foster care worker did not share all information related to complaints received
against the relatives Child A resided with in New York.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/8/2021 I interviewed the LGAL by telephone. The LGAL reported that on
10/27/2021 she emailed DHHS-WW asking that they provide her the results and all
copies of reports related to New York child protective services’ investigation(s). FCW
4 never responded to her request. Nor provided her all the information of possible
abuse/neglect allegations pertaining to Child A in the grandmother’s home. That as
of 11/8/2021 information requested pertaining to multiple allegations of possible
abuse/neglect in the grandmother’s home had not been provided. The only
information provided was that there were three complaints.
The LGAL reported DHHS-WW reported to the court on 10/20/2021 Child A’s mother
and Relative O were suspects related to the complaint incidents, but DHHS-WW
never informed her that Relative O was a suspect related to Child A’s bruises,
possible abuse/neglect incidents. The agency did not alert her there had been prior
incidents of concerns in Relative O’s home until the LGAL received a call from New
York.
On 11/12/2021 I spoke with Administrator 1, Supervisor 2, Program Manager 3, and
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4 via a TEAM’s video contact. I also received email
information from Administrator 1 on 11/16/2021. These staff advised that the LGAL
was apprised of the past allegations pertaining to possible abuse/neglect related to
Child A in Relative O’s care by the AAG at court and via the agency’s court report for
10/20/2021.
FCW 4 reported there were a total of three allegations that came to light. One on
10/6/2021 which she became aware of on 10/8/2021 related to a bruise on Child A’s
forearm. Another on 10/8/2021 that she learned about on 10/11/2021, which came
to light when Child A had been taken to the doctor for assessment related to the
10/6/2021 one. The 10/8/2021 allegation reportedly related to a scratch on Child A’s
eye that reportedly had occurred back in August 2021. New York was investigating
the issues; did not report the child being at risk or a need for Child A’s removal from
Relative O’s home at that time. FCW 4 reported they did not become aware of
allegations of Child A having a black eye until 10/25/2021. New York reported
noticing the black eye during Child A’s parenting time/visit at the office on
10/22/2021. New York also noticed Child A having a bruise to his chin. Child A was
taken to the doctor on 10/22/2021. New York reported the birth mother, the birth
mother’s boyfriend and Relative O were all possible suspects; and New York had
opened an investigation.
Administrator 1 reported the agency was informed by New York of an allegation on
10/6/2021 and the LGAL was provided the information related to the allegations on
10/8/2021 by the AAG at a court break session. It was FCW 4’s intention to relay
9

this information to the LGAL which FCW 4 had received in the evening of 10/7/2021.
However, an email was received from the AAG that the AAG had informed the LGAL
during a court break session earlier in the day on 10/8/2021. Additionally, the LGAL
attended the court hearing on 10/20/2021 in which those allegations from 10/6/2021
were reviewed, along with it being included in the court report for 10/20/2021 court
hearing. Administrator 1 reported the new allegations against the grandmother that
came out on 10/22/2021 have also been provided to the LGAL. She reported they
did not convey that information to the LGAL earlier. These matters were discussed
at the TDM 10/28/2021, which the LGAL was invited to attend, which the LGAL was
aware they would be discussing Child A’s placement stability. Administrator 1
reported at this point, they have shared all information that they have received from
New York Children Protective Services regarding all allegations. They have also
developed a plan to provide consistent updates to the LGAL moving forward in an
effort to improve their communication with her.
Reviewed
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
 Social work contacts entries by Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 on 10/6/2021 about
telephone calls with a New York worker and New York CPS supervisor,
respectively by each. The former call was of New York reporting allegations of
possible abuse or neglect after observing a bruise on Child A’s right forearm
during an unannounced visit at Child A’s school on 10/04/2021. The latter
contact by FCW 4 was follow up on the information reported by Supervisor 3.
Additionally, of DHHS-WW advising New York of their prior parent/child
visitation and safety planning conducted around Child A’s approved
unsupervised visit with his mother. Also of New York advising that New York
would complete an investigation on the complaint which would take 60 days;
and that a Child Safety Conference would be scheduled in the coming days.
That New York agreed to contact DHHS if Child A had any other marks or
bruises.
 A 10/14/2021 and 10/20/2021 social work contact by FCW 4, documented as
a weekly video conference via Google Duo with Child A and Relative O after
the reports of new allegations of abuse and neglect were received (the
contacts did not clarify what date the stated new allegation was received).
The social work contact noted: During the video contact FCW observed Child
A playing and observed fading marks on Child A’s right forearm at the
10/14/2021 contact. FCW 4 saw Child A playing and observed a small mark
on Child A’s forehead on 10/20/2021. Relative O reported Child A was
outside playing with his toys, was running and ran into the gate. Relative O
reported no concerns, Child A was continuing his services; Child A was
scheduled to complete a supervised parenting time visit with his mother at the
New York children service office on Friday on 10/22/2021.
 A 10/25/2021 social work entry for a telephone call from New York’s CPS
supervisor. The social work contact noted: The CPS supervisor advised of
Child A arriving an hour late for his scheduled supervised parenting time with
his mother at the New York Children Service office. That during that office
10

contact the New York worker and Child A’s mother noticed that Child A had a
black eye and additional bruising on his arm that was not present at the last
face to face visit with him. Child A was taken to the hospital, and it was
reported from the attending doctor that the new bruises didn’t appear to be
self-inflicted. Child A was removed from Relative O’s home and was
currently at the Children Center in New York. DHHS was requested to plan
for Child A’s transport back to Michigan as soon as possible since Michigan
has legal jurisdiction of Child A.
 A New York document of a 10/19/2021 Initial Child Safety Conference and
Recommendation related to Child A frequently sustaining unexplained marks
or bruises which indicated:
 The 10/6/2021 incident as described earlier in this report.
 The hospital where Child A was taken for examination could not
determine if the marks/bruises were self-inflicted or accidental.
 The birth mother denied Child A had marks or bruises when he last
visited her on 10/3/2021.
 Relative O reported believing Child A injured himself during play.
Relative O reported leaving Child A with a friend in August 2021 and
during that time Child A sustained an eye injury in from the cat.
Relative O also said on 10/14/2021 at 7:30pm while she was taking
out the trash Child A ran ahead of her and hit his head on the metal
door.
 The report recommended released to Relative O with supervision and
monitoring, continue therapy for Child A and his mother; and a mental
health assessment for Relative O. Additionally, that a neglect petition
be filed against Relative O and the mother because of Child A
frequency of sustaining unexplained marks.
 No documentation of a case contact to the LGAL showing that the
information noted in the above social works contacts or a complaint related to
Child A, being shared by FCW 4 to the LGAL prior.
A copy of the 10/20/2021 Court Hearing order that indicated:
 There was discussion around FCW 4 reporting becoming aware of an
abuse/neglect allegation pertaining to Child A for 10/6/2021.
 The LGAL was reported to be at that 10/20/2021 hearing.
Copies of emails back and forth between FCW 4 the AAG on 10/7/2021 and 10/8/2021
where:
 FCW 4’s apprised the AAG of her notification of the 10/6/2021 complaint
information of the new abuse complaint New York accepted for Relative O
and Child A’s mother; disclosure of Child A having bruises; no specifics as to
who or how the bruises were caused; a pending conference via TEAMs with
New York for 10/8/2021 at 10am.
11

 New York’s plans to complete a full investigation that could take 60-days.
Child A’s mother visits changing from unsupervised to supervised pending
New York CPS’ investigation completion.
 The AAG advising FCW 4 to keep him up to speed on the abuse/neglect
allegations pertaining to Child A’s relatives; and that if there is a change of
placement FCW 4 should immediately notify him and the LGAL. Additionally,
that the LGAL needs to be notified that as of now, a bruise was found on the
child’s arm, not requiring medical attention and is being investigated by New
York; if that is basically the truth. The AAG later informing FCW 4 he
informed the LGAL of this is new 10/6/2021 issue during a court hearing
docket break on10/8/2021. That the LGAL has requested the school and
teacher’s name and number, which can be provided to him, and he would
pass it on to the LGAL.
 FCW 4 sharing the outcome of the 10/8/2021 meeting with the AAG and
providing the school’s/teacher’s name and contact information to the AAG to
be shared with the LGAL by the AAG.
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
ANALYSIS: The agency worker did not work directly with Child A’s LGAL in
this incident on the complaint matters pertaining to Child A.
The agency/worker provided some but not all of the complaint
related information to the LGAL of allegations of possible
abuse/neglect of Child A while in Relative O’s home. The
agency admitted they did not disclose the complaint information
of 10/22/2021, when they received it, but have since done so.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
When the agency returned Child A to Michigan, they did not consider the prior foster
family. Instead, they placed him in another foster home.
INVESTIGATION:
The LGAL reported when Child A was returned to Michigan, instead of placing him
with FPS XX, which would have been in his best interest, Child A was placed with
12

Foster Parents Z. The LGAL expressed concern that DHHS-WW didn’t elect to
place Child A back with FPS XX because of upset with FPS XX over how Child A
was replaced from that foster home in the past. The LGAL expressed concern that
not placing Child A with a family he knew likely caused more trauma for him. The
LGAL visited Child A at Foster Parents Z’s home on 11/2/2021. Child A talked about
FPS XX. Child A still had a black eye, and he was fearful of being returned to New
York. The LGAL also expressed concern that DHHS-WW is now considering
placement with an aunt in New York whom Child A has no relationship with.
Administrator 1 reported it wasn’t that FPS XX were not considered for placement of
Child A. It was that they had concerns that FPS XX did not seem to support a goal of
reunification which remains Child A’s permanency plan. Additionally, the agency
wanted to get an independent assessment on what would be in his best interest.
They wanted a trauma assessment before considering a replacement back with FPS
XX. A trauma assessment was completed, and that assessment reported it was in
Child A’s best interest to go back to FPS XX. Child A was set to be placed with FPS
XX on 11/14/2021.
Supervisor 3 and Administrator 1 reported Child A’s goal is still reunification and
therefore they are charged with doing what is required to achieve that goal/what’s in
the best interest of Child A. Thus, an exploration of any relative, like the aunt who
resides in New York, where the mother continues to reside. FCW 4 reported seeing
Child A during a home visit with him and Foster Parents Z and Child A no longer had
a black eye.
Reviewed:
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which show:
 Information and documents as previously reported in this report.
 An Updated Service Plan for 8/6/2021-11/3/2021. This report showed
documentation that Foster Parents Z put in a 30-day request for Child A’s
removal.
 A DHS-69 showing Child A was replaced from Foster Parents Z’s foster home
to FPS XX foster home on 11/14/2021. This DHS-69 report indicated Foster
Parents Z did not feel Child A was a good fit for their home and they hoped
Child A would be placed with the original foster family he was with for three
years. This report also indicated Child A completed a trauma assessment on
11/10/2021 which recommended Child A be placement with his previous
foster parents, FPPS XX. Additionally, this DHS-69 indicated an ICPC request
for a home assessment of an aunt in New York was requested on 11/3/2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.12404 Placement.
(4) An agency shall consider all of the following in selecting an
appropriate placement for a child:
(e) The continuity of relationship, including relationships with
parents, siblings, relatives, foster parents, previous foster
13

parents and other persons significant to the child.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to support allegation that the
agency did not consider Child A’s prior foster parents, FPS XX
for placement upon his return to Michigan.
The agency had concern around FPS XX possible unwillingness
to support Child A’s permanency plan of reunification. They
sought to obtain an independent source to assess Child A’s
needs, what’s in his best interest, and give feedback around his
placement needs. A trauma assessment completed on
11/10/2021 recommended returning Child A to his prior foster
home; and the agency subsequently placed Child A with that
foster family on 11/14/2021.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-6H Case Contacts
TIMELY ENTRY OF CASE CONTACTS
All case contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, including
attempted contacts, and missed appointments.
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
ANALYSIS: During the investigation it was discovered the agency did not
timely document various case contacts. The agency did not
document email contacts with the AAG related to abuse/neglect
allegations pertaining to Child A. Additionally, there were
multiple social work entries for the time period 10/1/2021 -
11/3/2021 that were not entered during the 8/6/2021- 11/3/2021
service period.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
